image.title: Journal of Technical Writing and Communication

item.title: The Specialist in Athenian Written Rhetoric During the Classical Period: A Reconsideration of Technical Rhetoric and Rhetorical Iconography
item.content:encoded:
Journal of Technical Writing and Communication, Volume 52, Issue 4, Page 367-385, October 2022.
This essay argues that technical rhetoric in ancient Athens is neither well nor fully understood in its present historical characterization but rather is best realized as occupying a position on a spectrum of literate skills ranging from an art to a craft. The dismissive views of technical writing advanced by Plato and Aristotle should be reconsidered and specialized literate practices be recognized as an important feature of rhetoric in Athens’ classical period. A review of discursive and material (archaeological) evidence reveals that technical writing was evolving into a craft-skill in Athens as early as the archaic period and, by the classical period, would be regarded as a respected “rhetorical” profession of artistic expression. This essay urges readers to reconsider the restrictive characterization of rhetoric advanced by some historians of rhetoric and include the specialist craft-skills of writing as a manifestation of technical rhetoric that both illustrates, and more accurately represents, the range of classical rhetoric in ancient Athens.
item.description:
Journal of Technical Writing and Communication, Volume 52, Issue 4, Page 367-385, October 2022.

A review of discursive and material (archaeological) evidence reveals that technical writing was evolving into a craft-skill in Athens as early as the archaic period and, by the classical period, would be regarded as a respected “rhetorical” profession of artistic expression. This essay urges readers to reconsider the restrictive characterization of rhetoric advanced by some historians of rhetoric and include the specialist craft-skills of writing as a manifestation of technical rhetoric that both illustrates, and more accurately represents, the range of classical rhetoric in ancient Athens.
item.dc:title: The Specialist in Athenian Written Rhetoric During the Classical Period: A Reconsideration of Technical Rhetoric and Rhetorical Iconography
item.dc:source: Journal of Technical Writing and Communication
item.dc:creator: Richard Leo Enos
item.prism:publicationName: The Specialist in Athenian Written Rhetoric During the Classical Period: A Reconsideration of Technical Rhetoric and Rhetorical Iconography

item.title: Remote TPC Internships: Infrastructures for Success
item.content:encoded:
Journal of Technical Writing and Communication, Volume 52, Issue 4, Page 386-410, October 2022.
Though the remote internship is certainly not a new phenomenon, the COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated the growth of this model for undergraduate experiential learning. As we consider this shift, we must evaluate how to best assist students completing remote internships. In this article, we argue that infrastructure offers a useful framework for understanding students’ internship experience and corresponding professionalization. We present two case studies of student remote internship experiences, analyzing areas of challenge and success through the infrastructural areas of writing projects, communication, and logistics. We offer recommendations for faculty working with remote student interns to promote positive learning experiences.
item.description:

We offer recommendations for faculty working with remote student interns to promote positive learning experiences.
item.dc:title: Remote TPC Internships: Infrastructures for Success
item.dc:source: Journal of Technical Writing and Communication
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Bay
Gracemarie Mike Fillenwarth
Christine Masters-Wheeler
item.prism:publicationName: Remote TPC Internships: Infrastructures for Success

item.title: Communicating an Outbreak: The Visual Genres of Zika Virus Reports
item.content:encoded:
Journal of Technical Writing and Communication, Volume 52, Issue 4, Page 411-427, October 2022.
This article examines visuals used in the reporting of the 2015-2016 Zika virus outbreak in order to explore the use of different image forms and genres in communicating health information to distinct audiences. By tracing an informational report through several publication types, the use of different image forms and rhetorical genres are observed, as is the robustness and flexibility of these categorizations.
item.description:
Journal of Technical Writing and Communication, Volume 52, Issue 4, Page 411-427, October 2022.
This article examines visuals used in the reporting of the 2015-2016 Zika virus outbreak in order to explore the use of different image forms and genres in communicating health information to distinct audiences. item.dc:title: Communicating an Outbreak: The Visual Genres of Zika Virus Reports
item.dc:source: Journal of Technical Writing and Communication
item.dc:creator: Shannon N. Fanning
item.prism:publicationName: Communicating an Outbreak: The Visual Genres of Zika Virus Reports

item.title: Extending Design Thinking, Content Strategy, and Artificial Intelligence into Technical Communication and User Experience Design Programs: Further Pedagogical Implications
item.content:encoded:
Journal of Technical Writing and Communication, Volume 52, Issue 4, Page 428-459, October 2022.
This article follows up on the conversation about new streams of approaches in technical communication and user experience (UX) design, i.e., design thinking, content strategy, and artificial intelligence (AI), which afford implications for professional practice. By extending such implications to technical communication pedagogy, we aim to demonstrate the importance of paying attention to these streams in our programmatic development and provide strategies for doing so.
item.description:
Journal of Technical Writing and Communication, Volume 52, Issue 4, Page 428-459, October 2022.

item.dc:source: Journal of Technical Writing and Communication
item.dc:creator: Jason Tham
Tharon Howard
Gustav Verhulsdonck
item.prism:publicationName: Extending Design Thinking, Content Strategy, and Artificial Intelligence into Technical Communication and User Experience Design Programs: Further Pedagogical Implications

item.title: Defining the racial and ethnic “other”: Constructing an American identity through visualizing census data in the U.S. Statistical Atlases
item.content:encoded:
Journal of Technical Writing and Communication, Volume 52, Issue 4, Page 460-492, October 2022.
This study analyzes the visualization of census data in the U.S. Statistical Atlases from 1874 to 1925. I examine how visual strategies were used to construct an American identity by contrasting the “native” population with the “other”—new immigrants and African Americans, which were visualized as undesirable counterparts. By defining the “other,” the Atlases created a pan ethnic identity of the “native white” population, established a racial hierarchy, and hardened the division between old and new immigrants. The study develops a rhetorical framework for understanding how data design is used to marginalize racially and ethnically minority groups.
item.description:
Journal of Technical Writing and Communication, Volume 52, Issue 4, Page 460-492, October 2022.

The study develops a rhetorical framework for understanding how data design is used to marginalize racially and ethnically minority groups.
item.dc:title: Defining the racial and ethnic “other”: Constructing an American identity through visualizing census data in the U.S. Statistical Atlases
item.dc:source: Journal of Technical Writing and Communication
item.dc:creator: Li Li
item.prism:publicationName: Defining the racial and ethnic “other”: Constructing an American identity through visualizing census data in the U.S. Statistical Atlases

item.title: Examining Multimodal Community-Engaged Projects for Technical and Professional Communication: Motivation, Design, Technology, and Impact
item.content:encoded:
Journal of Technical Writing and Communication, Ahead of Print.
This study examines the role of multimodality in facilitating service-learning goals. We report findings from qualitative interviews with 20 college instructors who have designed and facilitated multimodal community-engaged learning projects, identifying their motivations, goals, and the impact of these projects through reflections. Based on our qualitative analysis of these instructor responses, we discuss the technological and pedagogical implications of multimodal social advocacy projects in technical and professional writing courses.
item.description:
Journal of Technical Writing and Communication, Ahead of Print.
This study examines the role of multimodality in facilitating service-learning goals. We report findings from qualitative interviews with 20 college instructors who have designed and facilitated multimodal community-engaged learning projects, identifying their motivations, goals, and the impact of these projects through reflections. Based on our qualitative analysis of these instructor responses, we discuss the technological and pedagogical implications of multimodal social advocacy projects in technical and professional writing courses.
item.dc:title: Examining Multimodal Community-Engaged Projects for Technical and Professional Communication: Motivation, Design, Technology, and Impact
item.dc:source: Journal of Technical Writing and Communication
item.dc:creator: Jason Tham
Jialei Jiang
item.prism:publicationName: Examining Multimodal Community-Engaged Projects for Technical and Professional Communication: Motivation, Design, Technology, and Impact

item.title: You Shall Not Pass? The Design of Age Gates in an Emerging Cannabis Market
item.content:encoded:
Journal of Technical Writing and Communication, Ahead of Print.
Age gates are becoming common on the websites of cannabis dispensaries, following design practices in other controversial industries. Yet, age gates can typically be bypassed through trial and error or basic arithmetic, raising questions over best practices. This study therefore characterized the age gates of dispensaries licensed in the Arizona adult use cannabis program, using a “digital mystery shopper” approach to examine the age gates’ location, appearance, and performance. After presenting the results, I outline possible best practices and next steps for technical and professional communicators.
item.description:
Journal of Technical Writing and Communication, Ahead of Print.

After presenting the results, I outline possible best practices and next steps for technical and professional communicators.
item.dc:title: You Shall Not Pass? The Design of Age Gates in an Emerging Cannabis Market
item.dc:source: Journal of Technical Writing and Communication
item.dc:creator: Michael J. Madson
item.prism:publicationName: You Shall Not Pass? The Design of Age Gates in an Emerging Cannabis Market

item.title: Collaborating Successfully with Community Partners and Clients in Online Service-Learning Classes
item.content:encoded:
Journal of Technical Writing and Communication, Ahead of Print.
Teaching online students to collaborate effectively with community partners and to solve problems through service-learning projects are “on trend” topics for technical communication faculty. This article presents collaboration specifics as well as the author's Collaborative Communication Framework (CCF) to show the types of communication needed to work well with community partners/clients in service-learning. Tips for teaching, including using the CCF and service-learning, will be highlighted so faculty can make choices about how to meet curricular goals while addressing community partner/client needs. Resources for teaching will be offered. Successful student projects will show detailed examples of key ideas throughout the article.
item.description:
Journal of Technical Writing and Communication, Ahead of Print.

item.dc:source: Journal of Technical Writing and Communication
item.dc:creator: Rebecca J. Dumlao
item.prism:publicationName: Collaborating Successfully with Community Partners and Clients in Online Service-Learning Classes

item.title: Tactical Technical Communication and Player-Created (DIY) Patch Notes: A Case Study
item.content:encoded:
Journal of Technical Writing and Communication, Ahead of Print.
Relying on rhetorical analysis, this article explores the rhetoric and ethics of a particular type of designer- and player-created technical communication genre, video patch notes, to further explore how various technical communication genres structure the experience of play. By providing a case study of official video patch notes for the game Overwatch in combination with Youtube user dinoflask's satirical fan made videos, the article examines both developers’ communication practices and the ways in which players creatively negotiate and re-purpose these practices in order to illustrate how such tactical technical communication remixes sustain a subtle dialogue between players and developers. This dialogue in particular illuminates pain points between stakeholders (in this case, discrepancies between developer intent and player experience) in ways that could potentially offer a means of persuading particularly ideologically fixed audiences, highlighting how practitioners might use tactical technical communication with activist intent.
item.description:
Journal of Technical Writing and Communication, Ahead of Print.

By providing a case study of official video patch notes for the game Overwatch in combination with Youtube user dinoflask's satirical fan made videos, the article examines both developers’ communication practices and the ways in which players creatively negotiate and re-purpose these practices in order to illustrate how such tactical technical communication remixes sustain a subtle dialogue between players and developers. This dialogue in particular illuminates pain points between stakeholders (in this case, discrepancies between developer intent and player experience) in ways that could potentially offer a means of persuading particularly ideologically fixed audiences, highlighting how practitioners might use tactical technical communication with activist intent.
item.dc:title: Tactical Technical Communication and Player-Created (DIY) Patch Notes: A Case Study
item.dc:source: Journal of Technical Writing and Communication
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Caravella
Steve Holmes
item.prism:publicationName: Tactical Technical Communication and Player-Created (DIY) Patch Notes: A Case Study

item.title: Slow Civic Violence and the Removal of USPS Mail Sorting Machines During the 2020 Election
item.content:encoded:
Journal of Technical Writing and Communication, Ahead of Print.
This article combines historical research with demographic analysis and neoliberal/rhetorical critique to put forth the concept of slow civic violence—indirect injuries on civic process, particularly within marginalized communities. The author ties the United States Postal Service's (USPS) rationale for removing mail sorting machines during the 2020 election year to systemic moves that damage democratic participation. The author conducts an empirical analysis of where the USPS mail sorting machines were removed to show how neoliberal arguments in favor of cost cutting make voting by mail a more precarious and uncertain act primarily for those who reside in communities of color.
item.description:
Journal of Technical Writing and Communication, Ahead of Print.

item.dc:title: Slow Civic Violence and the Removal of USPS Mail Sorting Machines During the 2020 Election
item.dc:source: Journal of Technical Writing and Communication
item.dc:creator: Fernando Sánchez
item.prism:publicationName: Slow Civic Violence and the Removal of USPS Mail Sorting Machines During the 2020 Election
